name: K2-58
scenarioDescription:
The K2-58 Exoplanetary System

K2-58 is a star with 0.89 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.86 times its radius. It is located 595.85 light years away from the solar system.

K2-58 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-58 b

K2-58 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.05 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-58.

The mass of K2-58 b is 10.24 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-58 b is 2.68 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-58 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

K2-58 c

K2-58 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.54 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-58.

The mass of K2-58 c is 3.09 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-58 c is 1.62 that of Earth. At 3.09 Earth masses, K2-58 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-58 d

K2-58 d was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 22.88 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-58.

The mass of K2-58 d is 3.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-58 d is 1.71 that of Earth. At 3.51 Earth masses, K2-58 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-58, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by K2.
